author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: Shenzhen to Shanghai passengers arrested for protesting delay in business class
text:
View
comments
Three passengers are in trouble with the law after they claimed business class seats and refused to leave amid a three-hour flight delay in China.
Passengers were forced to wait inside the airport terminal in Shenzhen, a massive city north of Hong Kong, as the China Southern Airlines plane was held on the ground by bad weather.
But several travellers were so enraged when they boarded they decided to sit in unoccupied – and roomier – business class seats instead of their assigned seats in economy.
Three passengers were arrested by local police when the China Southern Airlines plane landed (file photo)
The unruly passengers believed they were entitled to sit in business class as it would be ‘fair compensation’ following the delay suffered before a domestic flight, Want China Times reported.
Flight attendants managed to persuade most of the group to abandon their protest and take their seats in economy class, but three refused.

Forget crisps and a can of Coke: The world's most... They were allowed to fly to Shanghai in business class, but they were arrested by local police after the plane landed.
A spokesperson for China Southern Airlines told The Paper, a news website based in Shanghai, every plane needs to maintain an even distribution of passengers based on a pre-booked seating chart, and a plane is more likely to crash if passengers re-arrange their seats, according to Want China Times.
The unruly passengers believed business class seats would be 'fair compensation' after the delay (file photo)
The airline urged passengers to follow the crew’s instructions for the safety of others.
Last week, 10 passengers were injured on evacuation slides as they disembarked a China Southern Airlines plane that was forced to make an emergency landing.
The plane, carrying 132 passengers and seven crew members, made the unscheduled landing at the airport in the city of Sanya after a fire alarm went off on board.
It was travelling from Guangzhou to Bangkok, and investigators determined a fire did not occur.
